State Court Abortion Litigation Tracker

LinkedIn






Numerous challenges to abortion bans have been filed in state courts since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.


Last Updated: January 11, 2024
Published: December 5, 2022











egearing/Getty










This tracker is a joint project of the Center for Reproductive Rights and the Brennan Center for Justice.
In June 2022, the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, the nearly 50-year-old landmark ruling that the federal Constitution protects a right to abortion. In the wake of the Court’s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, a number of states quickly moved to enforce abortion bans and restrictions, spurring a slate of emergency litigation to protect reproductive rights under state law. In this tracker, the Brennan Center for Justice and the Center for Reproductive Rights aggregate pending and completed state court litigation against bans that were, or would have been, unconstitutional under Roe.
This is not a summary of abortion access in the states — for information on the current status of state abortion bans and restrictions, as well as laws protecting abortion access in the states, please see the Center for Reproductive Rights’s After Roe Fell: Abortion Laws by State. To learn about state court decisions that established state constitutional protections for abortion rights prior to Dobbs, please see the report on State Constitutions and Abortion Rights.
As of January 11, 2024, a total of 40 cases have been filed challenging abortion bans in 23 states, of which 22 remain pending at either the trial or appellate levels.
So far, the South Carolina Supreme Court held that its state constitution protects the right to an abortion and struck down a 6-week ban, but then reversed course to uphold a virtually identical ban a few months later. The Idaho Supreme Court has ​held that the state constitution does not protect the right to abortion.
Several courts have also declared that their state constitutions provide limited rights to abortion. For instance, the North Dakota Supreme Court and the Indiana Supreme Court have ruled that their state constitutions protect the right to an abortion when necessary to preserve life or health. The Oklahoma Supreme Court has ruled that its state constitution protects the right to an abortion when needed to preserve the life of the patient.

Arizona





Planned Parenthood v. Brnovich, No. C127867 (Ariz. Super. Ct. July 22, 1971)


Plaintiff(s): Planned Parenthood Center of Tucson and Planned Parenthood of Arizona
Defendant(s): Mark Brnovich
Law(s) challenged: Pre-Roe near-total abortion ban (A.R.S. § 13–3603)
Description: After the U.S. Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade, a state court blocked Arizona’s pre-Roe near-total ban. In the wake of Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, Arizona’s attorney general asked the state court to lift its injunction. In response, the plaintiffs argue that Arizona’s abortion laws need to be harmonized, which would mean that the pre-Roe ban does not apply to abortions provided by licensed physicians and must remain blocked to that extent. An intermediate appeals court temporarily blocked the ban, reversing the trial court’s order that had allowed the ban to take effect. The Arizona Supreme Court has agreed to review the decision
Key Documents
Rule 60(b) motion (July 13, 2022)
Response to Rule 60(b) motion (July 20, 2022)
Rule 60(b) ruling (September 22, 2022)
Order granting stay (October 7, 2022)
Order blocking ban (December 30, 2022)






Isaacson v. Arizona, No. CV2022-13091 (Ariz. Super. Ct. Oct. 3, 2022)


Plaintiff(s): Paul A. Isaacson, M.D. and Arizona Medical Association
Defendant(s): State of Arizona
Law(s) challenged: Pre-Roe near-total abortion ban (A.R.S. § 13–3603)
Description: Plaintiffs request a declaratory judgment that would harmonize Arizona’s
    pre-Roe near-total ban with later state laws that regulate legal abortions so that
    licensed physicians can provide the procedure. The case is stayed pending a resolution of Planned
        Parenthood v. Brnovich, No. C127867 (Ariz. Sup. Ct. July 22, 1971).

Florida





Generation to Generation v. Florida, No. 2022 CA 980 (Fla. Cir. Ct. Aug. 9, 2022) [CASE IS CONCLUDED]


Plaintiff(s): Generation to Generation, Inc., d/b/a Congregation L’Dor Va-Dor; Rabbi Arthur Waskow; and The Shalom Center 
Defendant(s): State of Florida; Ron DeSantis; Florida Department of Health; Joseph Ladapo, M.D.; Florida Board of Medicine; David Diamond, M.D.; Florida Board of Osteopathic Medicine; Sandra Schwemmer, D.O.; Florida Board of Nursing; Maggie Hanssen, M.H.R.S.N.; Florida Agency for Health Care Administration; Simone Marstiller, J.D.; and Ashley Moody 
Law(s) challenged: 15-week abortion ban (H.B. 5)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the ban violates the state constitution’s 1) right to privacy (Art. I, § 23), 2) Free Exercise Clause (Art. 1, § 3), 3) Establishment Clause (Art. 1, § 3), 4) prohibition on penalizing the practice of Judaism (Art. 1, § 3), 5) guarantee of due process — the law is insufficiently clear (Art. I, § 9), 6) guarantee of basic rights — violates equality (Art. 1, § 2), and 7) Freedom of Speech Clause (Art. I, § 4). They also claim it violates state law, specifically the Florida Religious Freedom Restoration Act (Fla. Stat. § 761.01). The plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case in October 2023.
Key Documents
Complaint (August 9, 2022)






Planned Parenthood v. Florida, No. 2022 CA 912 (Fla. Cir. Ct. June 1, 2022)


Plaintiff(s): Planned Parenthood of Southwest and Central Florida; Planned Parenthood of South, East, and North Florida; Gainesville Woman Care, LLC d/b/a Bread and Roses Women’s Health Center; A Woman’s Choice of Jacksonville, Inc.; Indian Rocks Woman’s Center, Inc. d/b/a Bread and Roses; St. Petersburg Woman’s Health Center, Inc.; Tampa Woman’s Health Center, Inc.; and Shelly Hsiao-Ying Tien, M.D., M.P.H.
Defendant(s): State of Florida; Ginger Bowden Madden; Jack Campbell; John Durrett; Melissa W. Nelson; William Gladson; Bruce Bartlett; R.J. Larizza; Brian S. Kramer; Monique Worrell; Brian Haas; Katherine Fernandez Rundle; Ed Brodsky; Andrew H. Warren; Larry Basford; David A. Aronberg; Dennis W. Ward; Harold F. Pryor; Philip G. Archer; Thomas Bakkedahl; Amira D. Fox; Florida Department of Health; Joseph Ladapo, M.D.; Florida Board of Medicine; Devid Diamond, M.D.; Florida Board of Osteopathic Medicine; Sandra Schwemmer, D.O.; Florida Board of Nursing; Maggie Hansen, M.H.Sc., R.N.; Florida Agency for Health Care Administration; and Simone Marstiller, J.D.
Law(s) challenged: 15-week abortion ban (H.B. 5)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the ban violates the state constitution’s right to privacy (Art. I, § 23). A trial court temporarily blocked the ban. An intermediate appeals court then reversed the trial court, allowing the ban to take effect. The Florida Supreme Court declined to block the ban while it hears an appeal.

Complaint (July 1, 2022)
Temporary injunction Order (July 5, 2022)
Order denying motion to vacate stay (July 21, 2022)
Order reversing temporary injunction (August 24, 2022)

Hafner v. Florida *[Full Case Name Below]


*Hafner v. Florida, No. 2022–14370-CA-01 (Fla. Cir. Ct. Aug. 1, 2022); Chotso v. Florida, No. 2022–14371-CA-01 (Fla. Cir. Ct. Aug. 1, 2022); Doe v. Florida, No. 2022–14372-CA-01 (Fla. Cir. Ct. Aug. 1, 2022); Pomerantz v. Florida, No. 2022–14373-CA-01 (Fla. Cir. Ct. Aug. 1, 2022); Capo v. Florida, No. 2022–14374-CA-01 (Fla. Cir. Ct. Aug. 1, 2022)
Plaintiff(s): Laurinda Hafner; Lama Karma Chotso; John/Jane Doe; Rabbi Gayle Pomerantz, Rabbi Robyn Fisher, and Rabbi Jason Rosenberg; and Rev. Tom Capo
Defendant(s): State of Florida; Ashley Moody; Ginger Bowden Madden; Jack Campbell; John Durrett; Melissa W. Nelson; William Gladson; Bruce Bartlett; R.J. Larizza; Brian S. Kramer; Monique H. Worrell; Brian Haas; Katherine Fernandez Rundle; Ed Brodsky; Andrew H. Warren; Larry Basford; David A. Aronberg; Dennis W. Ward; Harold F. Pryor; Philip G. Archer; Thomas Bakkedahl; and Amira D. Fox
Law(s) challenged: 15-week abortion ban (H.B. 5)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the ban violates the state constitution’s 1) Freedom of Speech Clause (Art. I, § 4) and 2) Free Exercise Clause (Art. 1, § 3). They also claim it violates the U.S. Constitution’s 1) Freedom of Speech Clause (Amend. I), 2) Free Exercise Clause (Amend. I), and 3) Establishment Clause (Amend. I). Finally, they claim it violates state law, specifically the Florida Religious Freedom Restoration Act (Fla. Stat. § 761.01). A trial court declined to temporarily block the law.

Georgia





Sistersong v. Georgia, No. 2022CV367796 (Ga. Super. Ct. Jul. 26, 2022)


Plaintiff(s): Sistersong Women of Color Reproductive Justice Collective; Feminist Women’s Health Center; Planned Parenthood Southeast, Inc.; Atlanta Comprehensive Wellness Clinic; Atlanta Women’s Medical Center; Femhealth USA d/b/a Carafem; Summit Medical Associates; P.C., Carrie Cwiak, M.D., M.P.H.; Lisa Haddad, M.D., M.S., M.P.H.; Eva Lathrop, M.D., M.P.H.; and Medical Students for Choice
Defendant(s): State of Georgia
Law(s) challenged: Six-week abortion ban (H.B. 481)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the ban violates the state constitution’s 1) right to liberty and privacy (as guaranteed by Art. I, § 1, ¶ I (due process) and ¶ XXIX (inherent rights)) and 2) guarantee of equal protection (Art. I, § 1, ¶ 2). They also argue that the ban is void because it violated federal constitutional precedent when it was enacted, and under Georgia jurisprudence, a subsequent change in federal law cannot revive such a law. A trial court struck down the ban as void, but the Georgia Supreme Court reversed the trial court’s order, upheld the ban, and remanded the case for consideration of the plaintiffs’ state constitutional claims.

Complaint (July 26, 2022)
Order denying preliminary injunction (August 15, 2022)

Adkins v. Idaho, CV01-23-14744 (Idaho Dist. Ct. Sept. 11, 2023)


Petitioner(s): Jennifer Adkins, Jillaine St.Michel, Kayle Smith, Rebecca Vincen-Brown, Emily Corrigan, M.D., Julie Lyons, M.D., and Idaho Academy of Family Physicians.
Respondent(s): State of Idaho, Brad Little, Raúl Labrador, and Idaho State Board of Medicine
Law(s) challenged: Scope of medical exceptions to near-total abortion ban (Idaho Code Section 18–622(2)) and six-week abortion ban (Idaho Code Section 18–8801(5))
Description: Plaintiffs seek a declaratory judgment that the medical exceptions to Idaho’s abortion bans permit physicians to provide abortion care to pregnant people with emergent medical conditions that pose a risk to their health. They also request a ruling that any enforcement of the bans by state officials against physicians who provide abortion care to such people would be beyond the scope of the official’s authority. Additionally, they claim that the bans, as applied to pregnant people with emergent medical conditions, violate the state constitution’s 1) rights to enjoy and defend life, pursue happiness, and secure safety (Art. I., §§ 1, 13) and 2) guarantee of equal protection (Art. I, §§ 1, 2). Finally, they claim that the bans, as applied to Idaho-licensed physicians treating pregnant people with emergent medical conditions, violate the state constitution’s 3) rights to acquire, possess, and protect property and due process (Art. I, §§ 1, 13). A trial court partially rejected the state’s motion to dismiss, holding that the exceptions to the abortion bans need to be interpreted through a declaratory judgment and allowing the plaintiffs’ claim that the bans violate the state constitution’s inalienable rights clause (Art. I., § 1), as applied to people with emergent medical conditions, to proceed.
Key Documents:
Complaint (September 11, 2023)
Memorandum of Decision and Order on Motion to Dismiss (December 29, 2023)






Planned Parenthood v. Idaho, No. 49615-2022 (Idaho Sup. Ct. Mar. 30, 2022) [CASE IS CONCLUDED] 


Petitioner(s): Planned Parenthood Great Northwest, Hawaii, Alaska, Indiana, Kentucky and Caitlin Gustafson, M.D.
Respondent(s): State of Idaho
Law(s) challenged: Six-week abortion ban that only permits private enforcement (S.B. 1309)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the ban violates the state constitution’s 1) separation of powers doctrine (Art. II, § 1), 2) prohibition on special legislation (Art. III, § 19), 3) guarantee of informational privacy (Art. I, §§ 1, 2, 17, 21), 4) guarantee of due process — prohibition on excessive and vague penalties (Art. I, § 13), 5) guarantee of equal protection (Art. I, §§ 1, 2), and 6) fundamental right to privacy in making intimate familial decisions (Art. I, §§ 1, 13, 17, 21). After the Idaho Supreme Court temporarily blocked the ban, it later allowed the ban to take effect pending a decision on the merits. The Court then declined to permanently block the ban, reasoning that the Idaho Constitution does not implicitly provide a fundamental right to an abortion because such a right is not “deeply rooted” in the state’s traditions and history.

Indiana





Planned Parenthood v. Members of the Medical Licensing Board of Indiana, No. 53C06-2208-PL-1756 (Ind. Cir. Ct. Aug. 31, 2022)


Plaintiff(s): Planned Parenthood Great Northwest, Hawaii, Alaska, Indiana, Kentucky; Women’s Med Group Professional Corporation; Whole Woman’s Health Alliance; All-Options, Inc.; and Amy Caldwell, M.D.
Defendant(s): Members of the Medical Licensing Board of Indiana; Hendricks County Prosecutor; Lake County Prosecutor; Marion County Prosecutor; Monroe County Prosecutor; St. Joseph County Prosecutor; Tippecanoe County Prosecutor; and Warrick County Prosecutor
Law(s) challenged: Near-total abortion ban (S.B. 1)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the ban violates the state constitution’s 1) substantive due process right to privacy included in the inherent rights clause (Art. I, § 1), 2) guarantee of equal privileges and immunities (Art. I, § 23), and 3) due course of law clause through its unconstitutionally vague language (Art. I, § 12). A trial court preliminarily blocked the ban. After keeping the injunction temporarily in place while it heard an appeal, the Indiana Supreme Court ruled on the merits of whether the Indiana Constitution protects a right to abortion and vacated the trial court’s preliminary injunction. According to the court, the state constitution’s due process right to privacy (Art. I, § 1) does not protect the right to abortion except when necessary to protect the patient’s life or to protect a patient from a serious health risk. Though the court acknowledged that the plaintiffs had previously withdrawn their vagueness claim (Art. I, § 12), it declined to rule on their privileges and immunities claim (Art. I, § 23) since that claim was not part of the appeal. The Indiana Supreme Court denied the request for rehearing, allowing the ban to take effect. The plaintiffs then filed an amended complaint to challenge both the ban’s medical exception for patients facing a serious health risk and its requirement that abortion care occur in hospitals or an ambulatory outpatient surgical center majority owned by a hospital as violations of the state constitution’s inherent rights clause.

EMW Women’s Surgical Center v. Cameron, No. 22-CI-3225 (Ky. Cir. Ct. June 27, 2022) [CASE IS CONCLUDED]


Plaintiff(s): EMW Women’s Surgical Center, P.S.C.; Ernest Marshall, M.D.; and Planned Parenthood Great Northwest, Hawaii, Alaska, Indiana, Kentucky, Inc.
Defendant(s): Daniel Cameron
Law(s) challenged: Near-total abortion ban (KRS 311.772) and six-week ban (KRS 311.7701–11)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the state’s near-total ban (triggered by the U.S. Supreme Court overturning Roe) violates the state constitution’s 1) right to privacy as contained in guarantees of liberty (§§ 1(1), 1(3), 2); 2) liberty right to self-determination (§§ 1(1), 1(3), 2); 3) prohibition on unlawful delegation of legislative authority to define the scope of Kentucky criminal law (§§ 27–29); 4) prohibition on enacting a ban that doesn’t require the Kentucky General Assembly’s approval to take effect (§ 60); 5) guarantee of due process — the law is insufficiently clear (§ 2); and 6) prohibition on unintelligible laws (§ 27–29). 
Plaintiffs also claim that the state’s six-week ban violates the state constitution’s 1) right to privacy as contained in guarantees of liberty (§§ 1(1), 1(3), 2) and 2) liberty right to self-determination (§§ 1(1), 1(3), 2).
After a trial court preliminarily blocked the bans, an intermediate appeals court reversed the trial court, allowing the bans to take effect. The Kentucky Supreme Court then declined to reinstate the temporary injunction, reasoning that the plaintiffs did not have standing to assert the rights of their patients and could not bring related constitutional claims against the six-week and near-total bans while declining to address whether the Kentucky Constitution protects abortion. The Court, however, concluded that the plaintiffs did have standing to bring non-delegation and General Assembly approval claims against the near-total ban on behalf of themselves and remanded the case to the trial court. The parties then agreed to the dismissal of the case.

Access Independent Health Services, Inc. v. Wrigley, No. 08-2022-CV-1608 (N.D. Dist. Ct. July 6, 2022)


Plaintiff(s): Access Independent Health Services, Inc., d/b/a Red River Women’s Clinic and Kathryn L. Eggleston, M.D.
Defendant(s): Drew H. Wrigley and Birch P. Burdick
Law(s) challenged: 2007 near-total abortion ban (North Dakota Century Code Section 12.1–31–12); 2023 near-total abortion ban (S.B. 2150)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the state’s near-total ban violates the state constitution’s guarantee of inalienable rights, including life, liberty, safety, and happiness, which are protected through the due process clause (Art. I, §§ 1, 12). A trial court preliminarily blocked the ban. On appeal, the North Dakota Supreme Court ruled that the trial court did not properly assess all the factors for issuing preliminary relief and ordered the trial court to reassess whether each of those factors had been satisfied. Upon doing so, the trial court again blocked the ban. The North Dakota Supreme Court subsequently upheld the trial court’s preliminary injunction of the ban. The Court first concluded that the text of the state constitution and North Dakota’s history and traditions reveal that there is a fundamental right to an abortion when necessary to preserve the life or health of the patient. It then determined that the ban is not narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling state interest. The Court declined to rule on whether the state constitution protects the right to abortion beyond a situation in which the pregnant person’s life or health is at risk.
The plaintiffs subsequently amended their complaint to challenge a second near-total ban passed by the legislature in 2023, which they claim violates the state constitution’s 1)  guarantee of due process — the exceptions to the ban are insufficiently clear (Art. I, § 12) and 2) guarantee of inalienable rights, including life, liberty, safety, and happiness, which are protected through the due process clause, because the ban prohibits abortions when needed to protect the pregnant person’s mental health or when the fetus is unlikely to survive the pregnancy and sustain life after birth (Art. I, §§ 1, 12).

The Ohio Supreme Court agreed to hear the state’s appeal limited to the questions of whether the appeal was premature, and whether the challengers have standing. It declined to address on this appeal whether the Ohio Constitution guarantees a right to abortion before. later dismissing the appeal and remanding to the trial court, in light of the state constitution’s new reproductive freedom amendment. The plaintiffs have moved to file an amended complaint to add a new claim under the amendment.

II, § 7), 2) guarantee of due process — right to health (Art. II, § 7), 3) guarantee of equal protection (Art. II, § 7), 4) right to open courts (Art. II, § 6), 5) prohibition on special laws (Art. They also argue that Oklahoma precedent prevents the legislature from delegating the state’s police power to private citizens.
The Oklahoma Supreme Court declined to temporarily block the two bans pending a decision on whether to take jurisdiction of the case and rule on the merits. The Court subsequently assumed jurisdiction over the case and applied its recent precedent holding that the Oklahoma constitution protects abortion when necessary to preserve a patient’s life. Law(s) challenged: Pre-Roe near-total abortion ban (Oklahoma Stat. Tit. 21, section 861) and 2022 near-total abortion ban (S.B. 612)
Description: Plaintiffs claim that the bans violate the state constitution’s 1) inherent right to personal autonomy and bodily integrity (Art. II, § 2), 2) guarantee of due process — right to health (Art. II, § 7), and 3) guarantee of due process — the laws are insufficiently clear (Art. II, § 7). They also seek a declaratory judgment that the pre-Roe ban was repealed by implication. The Oklahoma Supreme Court summarily denied the plaintiffs’ request to block the bans pending a decision on whether to take jurisdiction of the case and rule on the merits. The Court subsequently assumed jurisdiction over the case and ruled that the text of the state constitution and Oklahoma’s history and traditions reveal that there is an inherent right to an abortion when necessary to preserve the life of the patient. It then determined that while the pre-Roe ban is constitutional, the 2022 ban is unconstitutional as to its requirement that a pregnant person must wait until they are experiencing a medical emergency before seeking a life-saving abortion. It also concluded that the pre-Roe ban was not unconstitutionally vague nor repealed by implication. The Court declined to rule on whether the state constitution protects the right to abortion beyond a situation in which the pregnant woman’s life is at risk.
